Music types most studied: Lullabies, simple melodic songs, caregiver‑sung music
Typical positive effects: Calmer heart rate and better sleep; support for language, attention, and early motor coordination.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Overstimulating, loud, or very fast music can increase arousal and restlessness.
Example notes: In neonatal and pediatric care, structured music therapy can support development and reduce distress in at‑risk children.

Music types most studied: Play songs, pop, instrumental background music
Typical positive effects: Moderate, pleasant music can improve on‑task behavior, motivation, and some memory tasks.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Very loud or highly lyrical music can distract from demanding schoolwork and reduce performance.
Example notes: Effects often work through arousal and mood: music that is not too calm or too intense tends to help learning.

Typical positive effects: Self‑chosen music often reduces stress, improves mood, and supports identity and social connection.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Very aggressive or extremely sad music may maintain negative mood or rumination in some teens.
Example notes: Systematic reviews show music‑based programs can improve emotional regulation and overall mental health in adolescents.

Music types most studied: Wide range; self‑selected vs researcher‑selected music
Typical positive effects: Relaxing or liked music can reduce perceived stress, anxiety, and improve mood during tasks; may aid simple cognitive performance.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Not all studies find strong effects; in some experiments, music selection and gender showed little direct impact on stress or mood overall.
Example notes: Many lab studies use young adults for tests of working memory, attention, and emotion under different music conditions.

Music types most studied: Popular music from youth, classical, background music
Typical positive effects: Similar to young adults: preferred music helps mood regulation, stress reduction, and can support task engagement.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Very loud or distracting music may impair performance on complex tasks, especially under high workload.
Example notes: Some lifespan studies combine this group with “adults,” but note that preferences often shift toward familiar and less intense music.

Typical positive effects: Happy‑sounding or preferred music can elevate mood, optimize arousal, and support some cognitive tasks (e.g., processing speed, memory cues).
Typical negative / mixed effects: Very complex or unfamiliar music can be less engaging or fatiguing for some; effects vary with hearing and cognitive status.
Example notes: Older adults may experience stronger mood benefits from preferred music compared with younger adults after negative mood inductions.

Music types most studied: Relaxing, pleasant, and aversive music compared
Typical positive effects: Often show stronger emotional self‑reports and physiological responses to emotional or aversive music; relaxing music can reduce stress and anxiety.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Some studies report “hypersensitivity” to unpleasant or dissonant music, with larger stress‑related physiological reactions.
Example notes: Stress‑reduction studies show music improves emotional health in both genders, but intensity and pattern of response may differ in women.

Music types most studied: Relaxing, pleasant, and aversive music compared
Typical positive effects: Relaxing or self‑selected music reduces stress and improves mood; some work suggests men may benefit more from self‑chosen tracks than assigned music.
Typical negative / mixed effects: May report lower emotional intensity to the same music compared with women, though findings are mixed.
Example notes: Reviews note that overall mood and stress benefits of music occur in both men and women, while gender differences are usually moderate.

Group / condition (with age): Short‑term stress / anxiety (all ages, typically 13+ years in studies)
Typical positive effects: Lower self‑reported stress and anxiety, reduced heart rate and blood pressure, and improved perceived relaxation across many lab and clinical settings.
Typical negative / mixed effects: In high‑demand tasks, music with lyrics or very high tempo can interfere with concentration even if it feels pleasant.
Example notes: Studies in students and workers show music as a low‑cost strategy for acute stress relief and mood regulation.

Music types most studied: Calm music, patient‑preferred music, structured music therapy
Typical positive effects: Reductions in perceived pain, anxiety, and sometimes medication use; better coping and quality of life.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Effects are usually moderate, not a replacement for medical treatment; not every patient responds strongly.
Example notes: Music is often added as an adjunct in pain clinics, rehabilitation, and palliative care for supportive benefit.

Group / condition (with age): Long‑term neurological issues (e.g., stroke, acquired brain injury; children and adults)
Music types most studied: Rhythmic auditory stimulation, task‑oriented music therapy
Typical positive effects: Support for motor recovery (gait training), speech and language rehabilitation, and attention training.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Requires trained therapists and structured programs; not all domains (e.g., complex reasoning) improve equally.
Example notes: Integrating music therapy with physiotherapy or speech therapy can enhance rehabilitation outcomes in children and adults.

Music types most studied: Familiar songs, individualized playlists, group singing
Typical positive effects: Reduced agitation, improved mood and social interaction, temporary improvement in orientation and autobiographical recall.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Effects are usually short‑term and depend on matching music to the person’s history and preferences.
Example notes: Personalized playlists and group singing programs are widely used in dementia care homes to enhance quality of life.

Group / condition (with age): Depression and anxiety disorders (adolescents to older adults)
Music types most studied: Preferred relaxing music, active music therapy, songwriting
Typical positive effects: Decreases in depressive and anxiety symptoms when music therapy is added to standard care; better emotional expression and coping.
Typical negative / mixed effects: Very sad or repetitive rumination‑related listening habits can maintain low mood in some individuals.
Example notes: Systematic reviews show music‑based interventions have small‑to‑moderate positive effects on mood disorders.
